'''Information Kerala Mission''' [http://www.infokerala.org] (IKM),Is an Autonomous Institution under Local self government Department, Government of Kerala, for computerisation and networking of local governments in [[Kerala]] (India) and has been in existence for a decade since August 1999. The purpose of the Institution was to "facilitate easy and prompt communication between State Planning Board (SPB) and 1215 local 'bodies' for swift monitoring".<ref>Report of the Comptroller and Auditor General of India for the year ended 31 March 2004. P39</ref>
==Basic objective==
The basic objective of IKM is to provide vibrant Information technology [[e-governance]] to the local governments in Kerala.IKM attempts to strengthen local self-governance or third tier governance and development through ICT ([[Information and Communications Technology]]) applications. It envisages computerising and networking the 1223 '''local self-government institutions''' (LSGIs) in [[Kerala]]. It is the largest and most comprehensive [[local government]] computerisation project in [[India]]. It addresses the entire gamut of issues concerning local governance, decentralised planning, and local economic development.
Executive Director Of IKM- Seeram Sambasiva Rao IAS
==Phased implementation==
IKM envisages a phased transformation of the existing systems to electronic systems. It has developed methodologies that suit this purpose. IKM has adopted a human-centred approach to e-governance. This approach is characterised by the holistic and proactive evaluation of existing systems and legacy systems, attempts to simplify and transform existing systems and effecting integration of systems. Systematic attempts at process reforms are also part of it. These would enable faster and objective decision-making, more citizen-friendly interfaces and better accountability.
IKM Methodology places the employees and functionaries at the central stage of this transformation and focuses on their empowerment and capacity building as the mechanism for improving performance. The software applications are developed through active user participation. Emphasis is placed on demystification of technologies and establishing adequate technical support systems. Training and hand holding are given high priority. IKM has taken out extensive pilot deployment of its application suites.
==Application Software==
* [http://www.infokerala.org/sulekha/ '''Sulekha'''] : Plan Monitoring for decentralised planning at local level * [http://www.infokerala.org/sevana-civil-registration/ '''Sevana'''] : Civil Registration - Births, Deaths and Marriages Registration * [http://www.infokerala.org/sanchitha/ '''Sanchitha'''] : Repository of acts and rules relating to local bodies * [http://www.infokerala.org/soochika/ '''Soochika'''] : Work flow application. Status Monitoring over web, and eSMS integration * [http://www.infokerala.org/sanchaya/ '''Sanchaya'''] : The Revenue & Licence System * [http://www.infokerala.org/saankhya/ '''Saankhya'''] : Double entry accrual based accounting for all local governments * [http://www.infokerala.org/sthapana/ '''Sthapana'''] : Payroll, PF accounting (Municipal and Panchayat employees PF accounts) * [http://www.infokerala.org/samveditha/ '''Samvedhitha'''] : LSGD web portal for all local governments and the Department * [http://www.infokerala.org/sachithra/ '''Sachithra'''] : Map suite (GIS) and asset register for local governments * [http://www.infokerala.org/sevana-pension/ '''Sevana Pension'''] : Disbursement of social welfare pensions, with electronic money order (eMO) integration * [http://www.infokerala.org/sakarma/ '''Sakarma'''] : Handling of council/committee agenda, minutes, etc. * [http://www.infokerala.org/sugama/ '''Sugama'''] : Cost Estimation tool for public works * [http://www.infokerala.org/sanketham/ '''Sanketham'''] : Ensures transparency in granting Building Permits (KMBR) * [http://www.infokerala.org/subhadra/ '''Subhadra'''] : Financial Management System * [http://www.infokerala.org/samoohya/ '''Samoohya'''] : Citizen database * [http://www.infokerala.org/saphalya/ '''Saphalya'''] : Human resource package
==Online Services==
* [http://www.cr.lsgkerala.gov.in/ Birth & Death Registration] * [http://www.cr.lsgkerala.gov.in/Cmn_Application.php/ Marriage Registration & efiling] * [http://plan.lsgkerala.gov.in/ Plan Monitoring] * [http://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20170504105740/http://www.lsgkerala.gov.in/ LSGD Portal] * [https://www.tax.lsgkerala.gov.in/ Property Tax & epayment] * [http://welfarepension.lsgkerala.gov.in/ Social Security Pension] * [http://gis.lsgkerala.gov.in/ GIS Maps] * [http://www.finance.lsgkerala.gov.in/ Double Entry Accounting] * [http://filetracking.lsgkerala.gov.in/ File Tracking] * [http://www.lsgkerala.gov.in/kmbr/ Building Permit] * [http://kmpecpf.lsgkerala.gov.in/ Municipality Employees PF] * [http://kpepf.lsgkerala.gov.in/ Panchayat Employees PF] * [http://lsgkerala.gov.in/sanchitha2/Electronic Legal Advisor]
==Website for all local governments==
The [[Government of India]] envisaged a plan for creating a portal for rural local governments in the entire country including the State of Kerala, for which webserver was set up and templates for uploading of each website by the respective local government was envisaged. But it remains in cold storage now.
Now the [[Government of Kerala]], as part of the activities of IT Mission focusing on FOSS promotion,started working on a project for creating a website of each local government in Kerala. A few [http://azhikode.entegramam.gov.in/ websites in Malayalam] were created by using the [[Content Management System]] [http://www.joomla.org/ Joomla], as part of it.
==Audit charges against IKM== [[Image:IKMAudit2.png|right|480px|thumb| Snapshot from Audit Document of [[Comptroller and Auditor General of India]] ]] The public audit agency of Govt of India, [[Comptroller and Auditor General of India]] <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cag.gov.in |title=Comptroller and Auditor General |publisher=CAG}}</ref> had indicted charges of omission against the activities of Information Kerala Mission, after conducting detailed investigations into the affairs of the functioning of IKM.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cag.gov.in/html/LB/Kr/LB_08_CHAPTER_IV_.pdf |title=The CAG Audit Report (Local Self government Institutions for the year 2006-07 : Chapter 4 - TRANSACTION AUDIT, Kerala Information Network for Local Bodies |publisher=CAG}}</ref> In the audit document, [[Comptroller and Auditor General of India|CAG]] mentioned that the entire project had amongst many shortcomings,
# 'Absence of a well-conceived project report', # 'Inconsistent procurement policy', # 'Non-utilisation of Central Govt's assistance', # 'Wasteful expenditure expenses on technical persons', # 'Lack of Supervision', amongst other charges, and # 'Inconsistencies in its software'.
CAG hasn't lifted these audit observations till date.
Information Kerala Mission is widely accused <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.india-today.com/webexclusive/dispatch/20000729/rkrishnan1.html |title=Online Overdrive |publisher=India Today}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rediff.com/us/2000/jul/10us2.htm |title=MS accused of 'underhand deal' in Kerala |publisher=Rediff News}}</ref> of developing software solutions deploying proprietary services from Microsoft Inc, which goes against the 'letter and spirit' of the IT policy <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kerala.gov.in/annualprofile/it_07.pdf |title=IT Policy 2007, Govt of Kerala |publisher=Govt of Kerala |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090220045719/http://www.kerala.gov.in/annualprofile/it_07.pdf |archivedate=2009-02-20 |df= }}</ref> promulgated by the State Government. The IT policy insists that all public software solutions be developed only with Free Software.
==Awards== * Sulekha (Plan Formulation and Monitoring System for Decentralised Planning of Local Governments) won the Gold Medal in National Awards or e-governance 2009-10 by Government of India for under the category "Excellence in Government Process Re-engineering". Sevana (Civil Registration System and Hospital Kiosks) won Brownze medal under the category "Outstanding performance in Citizen-Centric Service Delivery" * [http://www.csinihilent-egovernanceawards.org/ CSI Nihilent e-governance Awards 2008-09] for Sulekha Plan Monitoring System for Decentralised Planning, Kerala
==See also==
* [[Local Governance in Kerala]] * [[Local eGovernment]] * [[My Gov]]

[[File:Fachongle Isaf - geograph.org.uk - 334733.jpg|thumb|[[Farm]] ''Fachongle Isaf'', where John Seymour lived during the 1970s]] '''John Seymour''' (12 June 1914 – 14 September 2004) was a prolific early author in the [[self-sufficiency]] movement. He had multiple roles as a writer, broadcaster, [[environmentalist]], [[agrarianism|agrarian]], [[Smallholding|smallholder]] and activist; a rebel against: [[consumerism]], [[industrialisation]], [[genetically modified organisms]], cities, motor cars; an advocate for: [[Individualism|self-reliance]], personal responsibility, self-sufficiency, conviviality (food, drink, dancing and singing), gardening, caring for the Earth and for the soil.
==Early life== Seymour was born in [[Hampstead]], [[London]], [[England]];<ref name=Girardet>{{cite news | url=http://money.guardian.co.uk/ethicalmoney/story/0,1356,1309292,00.html | title=Obituary: John Seymour, The Guardian, September 21, 2004 | accessdate=2 June 2007 | location=London | date=21 September 2004 | first=Herbert | last=Girardet}}</ref> his father died when he was very young,{{fact|date=February 2017}} his mother remarried and the family moved to the fashionable seaside town of [[Frinton-on-Sea]] in north-east [[Essex]].<ref name=Girardet/> It was however surrounded by agricultural land, and the life led by those on the land and in small boats laid a foundation for his later vision of a simple cottage economy with farming and fishing providing the essentials of life.
After schooling in England and Switzerland,{{fact|date=February 2017}} he studied agriculture at [[Wye College]],<ref name=Girardet/> at that time a school of the University of London. {{fact|date=February 2017}}In 1934, at the age of 20, he went to [[Southern Africa]] where he held a succession of jobs: a farmhand and then manager of a sheep farm, a deckhand and skipper of a fishing boat operating from [[Namibia]] (then [[South-West Africa]]), a copper mine worker in [[Zambia]] (then [[Northern Rhodesia]]), and a worker for the government veterinary service. Whilst in Africa he spent some time with [[bushmen]] where he gained friendship and an insight into the life of [[hunter gatherer]]s.
==1939 to 1951== At the start of [[World War II]] in 1939, Seymour travelled to [[Kenya]] where he enlisted in the [[Kenya Regiment]],{{fact|date=February 2017}} and was posted to the [[King's African Rifles]].<ref name=Girardet/> He fought against Italian troops in the [[East African Campaign (World War II)|Abyssinian Campaign]] in [[Ethiopia]]. The regiment was then posted to [[Sri Lanka]] (then the British colony Ceylon) and afterwards to [[Burma]], where allied forces were fighting against [[Japan]]. For Seymour the war ended on a low note; he expressed his disgust when the Allies used fission bombs on [[Hiroshima]] and [[Nagasaki, Nagasaki|Nagasaki]].
On arrival in Britain after the war Seymour worked for a while on a [[Thames sailing barge]], a traditional craft still operating around the south and east coasts of [[England]], where he picked up the folk songs of a disappearing occupation. After working as a labour officer for the Agricultural Committee finding agricultural work for German prisoners of war who still not returned home in 1950, he created a series of short programmes on the [[BBC Home Service]] (now [[BBC Radio 4|Radio 4]]). He then travelled overland to [[India]] for the BBC, gaining experience of the [[Subsistence agriculture]] still common in eastern Europe and Asia. His experiences on the journey led to his first book, ''The Hard Way to India'', published in 1951.
==The Smallholdings== Seymour was living aboard a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] sailing [[smack (ship)|smack]] when he married Sally Medworth, an [[Australia]]n [[pottery|potter]] and artist in 1954. In this they travelled around the waterways and rivers of [[England]] and the [[Netherlands]], journeys later described in ''Sailing through England''. As their first daughter grew older they felt that a land-base would be more suitable. They leased two isolated [[cottage]]s on {{convert|5|acre|ha|lk=on}} of land near [[Orford, Suffolk|Orford]] in [[Suffolk]]. These 5 acres are still called Seymour's Bit by the current owner. The manner in which they developed [[self-sufficiency]] on this [[smallholding]] is recounted in ''The Fat of the Land'' (1961). At the end of the 1960s, Seymour, along with other radical voices like [[Herbert Read]], [[Edward Goldsmith]] and [[E. F. Schumacher|Fritz Schumacher]], provided a stream of articles for the journal ''[[Resurgence & Ecologist|Resurgence]]'' edited from 1966–1970 by [[John Papworth]].
In 1964 the family moved to a farm near [[Newport, Pembrokeshire]]. The 1970s saw Seymour's publication rate reach a maximum. In 1976 ''The Complete Book of Self-Sufficiency'' was published, a guide for real and dreaming [[Downshifting (lifestyle)|downshifter]]s. Appearing shortly after the publication of Schumacher's ''[[Small Is Beautiful: A Study of Economics As If People Mattered]]'' (1973) and ''[[The Good Life (1975 TV series)|The Good Life's]]'' first showing on British television (1975), the sales of the book exceeded all expectations. It was also set to establish the reputation of two young publishers, [[Christopher Dorling]] and [[Peter Kindersley]] who had commissioned and edited the work. In addition to self-sufficiency he wrote four guide books in the ''Companion Guide'' series.
In the 1970s and 1980s he also made television programmes: an early series followed the footsteps of [[George Borrow]]'s ''Wild Wales'' (1862), later he spent three years making the BBC series ''Far From Paradise'' (with [[Herbert Girardet]]) which examined the history of [[human impact on the environment]].
His farm in Wales welcomed visitors seeking guidance on the smallholders life, a project which continued when he moved to [[County Wexford]] in Ireland during the 1980s. Here in 1999 he was taken to court for damaging a crop of GM sugar beet. For the last years of his life, he lived on his old Pembrokeshire farm with his daughter's family. He died there on 14 September 2004 and was buried in the top field in an orchard that he had planted.
==Legacy== His obituary in the Guardian said: :''John was as much at home in the humblest house on a hillside, as in the manor house of landed gentry. He was like a force of nature, always willing to listen, always interested in learning about new - or very old - ways of working the land. He was a one-man rebellion against modernism ...'' Herbert Girardet, 2005.<ref name=Girardet/>

'''Latvian Human Rights Committee''' ({{lang-lv|Latvijas Cilvēktiesību komiteja}}, {{lang-ru|Латвийский комитет по правам человека}}) is a human rights non-governmental organization in [[Latvia]]. It is member of international human rights and anti-racism NGOs [[FIDH]], AEDH<!-- and [[European Network Against Racism|ENAR]] -->. Co-chairpersons of LHRC are Vladimirs Buzajevs and Natalija Jolkina. According to the authors of the study "Ethnopolitics in Latvia", former CBSS Commissioner on Democratic Institutions and Human Rights [[Ole Espersen]] "had visited LHRC various times and had used mostly the data of that organisation in his views on Latvia".<ref>[http://providus.lv/article_files/1119/original/Etnopolitika_Latvija.pdf?1326909280 Etnopolitika Latvijā. Pārskats par etnopolitisko stāvokli Latvijā un tā ietekme uz sabiedrības integrāciju] Red. E. Vēbers. Rīga, 2001. LCCN [http://lccn.loc.gov/2002497534 2002497534] — 75. lpp.{{lv icon}}</ref>
==History== In 1992, LHRC was founded (then — as Latvian Human Rights and International Humanitarian Co-operation Committee) by a group of people co-operating since 1990, led by [[Tatjana Ždanoka]] and Vladimirs Bogdanovs. In 1995, LHRC has joined FIDH and was registered by Latvian authorities.
Since 1994, LHRC periodically publishes an updated list of differences in rights between citizens and [[Non-citizens (Latvia)|non-citizens]] of Latvia. Since 1997, LHRC supports [[UNITED for Intercultural Action]]. In 2007, LHRC has joined ENAR and AEDH.
==Publications== The following printed publications in English were issued or prepared by LHRC:
*Human Rights and Minorities in Latvia (1999) *Report on the Implementation of the Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities in the Republic of Latvia (2002)<ref>[http://www.lhrc.lv/arxiv/Report_Framework_2002_2.pdf Report on the Implementation of the Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities in the Republic of Latvia (2002)]</ref> *Media Legislation, Minority Issues, and Implications for Latvia (2003)<ref>[http://live2.algs.lv/i/doc/211d.pdf Media Legislation, Minority Issues, and Implications for Latvia]</ref> *Citizens of a Non-Existent State (2008; second edition 2011; includes the aforementioned list)<ref>Citizens of a Non-Existent State [http://www.lhrc.lv/biblioteka/CITIZENS_OF_A_NON_EXISTENT_STATE.pdf 2008] [http://rusojuz.lv/public/uploads/books/21/book.pdf 2011]</ref> *{{cite book |title=Chance to Survive: Minority Rights in Estonia and Latvia |editor1-first=Vadim |editor1-last=Poleshchuk |editor1-link=Vadim Poleshchuk |others= |year=2009 |publisher=Foundation for Historical Outlook |location=Moscow, Paris, Tallinn |isbn=978-9949-18-818-5 |page= |pages= |url=http://www.lichr.ee/main/assets/L-3-eng.pdf |accessdate=13 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110313081515/http://www.lichr.ee/main/assets/L-3-eng.pdf |archivedate=13 March 2011 |df= }} (prepared in co-operation with [[Legal Information Centre for Human Rights]]) *{{cite book |title=Legal and social situation of the Russian-speaking minority in Latvia. |author1-first=Vladimir |author1-last=Buzayev |year=2013 |publisher= Averti-R |location=Riga |isbn=978-9934-8245-1-7|url=http://www.russkije.lv/files/images/text/PDF_Files/Legal-and-social-situation.pdf}}
==Cases before international judicial bodies==
LHRC members have worked on the following cases before international human rights institutions:
*Agafonova v. Latvia (UN [[Human Rights Committee|HRC]]) — Latvia has issued residence permit for the applicant<ref>[http://www.eumap.org/reports/2001/minority/sections/latvia/minority_latvia.pdf Minority Protection in Latvia — Open Society Institute, 2001 — p. 311]</ref> *[[Ignatāne v. Latvia]] (UN HRC) — views in favour of Ignatane (2001)<ref>[http://hrlibrary.umn.edu/undocs/884-1999.html HRC views in case Ignatane v. Latvia]</ref> *[[Podkolzina v. page.title: List of prime ministers defeated by votes of no confidence

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=November 2015}}
This is a list of [[Prime Minister]]s defeated by either a parliamentary [[motion of no confidence]] or by the similar process of [[loss of supply]].
==Prime Ministers defeated by votes of no confidence== ===[[Australia]]=== {{refimprove section|date=November 2015}} No Australian prime minister has ever been defeated in the House of Representatives by an explicit motion of no confidence,<ref>Anne Twomey (2010, Sept 10), [http://www.smh.com.au/opinion/politics/joining-the-coalition-to-pass-policies-will-backfire-20100909-1532w.html Joining the Coalition to pass policies will backfire], ''Sydney Morning Herald''</ref> although one was passed by the Representatives.<ref name="NAA">{{cite web |url=http://naa.gov.au/collection/snapshots/dismissal/index.aspx |title=The motion that might have saved the Whitlam governmen |publisher=[[National Archives of Australia]] |access-date=12 September 2016}}</ref> In addition, six prime ministers were unable to enact important policy and therefore resigned, two prime ministers were unable to obtain supply from the House of Representatives, one prime minister was unable to obtain supply in the Senate and was dismissed by the Governor General, and one prime minister never had the confidence of the House of Representatives (but an election was announced when he was appointed, so his defeat was without effect).
These prime ministers were able to gain supply from the House of Representatives, but were unable to pass important policy-related legislation:
*[[Chris Watson]] (1904, [[Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904|''Conciliation and Arbitration Bill'']]) *[[George Reid (Australian politician)|George Reid]] (1905, amendment on the address-in-reply) *[[Alfred Deakin]] (1908, motion to change the time of the next meeting of parliament) *[[Andrew Fisher]] (1909, a motion to adjourn debate) *[[Stanley Bruce]] (1929, major bill defeated) *[[James Scullin]] (1931, a motion to adjourn debate) *[[Malcolm Fraser]] (1975, a motion by the Governor-General to reappoint [[Gough Whitlam]] as Prime Minister)
These prime ministers could not gain supply from the House of Representatives or an opposition amendment to a supply bill was passed:
*[[Alfred Deakin]] (1904, could pass no legislation) *[[Arthur Fadden]] (1941, budget was amended down by [[Australian pound|£A]]1)
[[Gough Whitlam]] could not gain supply from the Senate which was controlled by the [[Coalition (Australia)|conservative Coalition]]. It thus precipitated the [[Australian constitutional crisis of 1975|1975 constitutional crisis]] and Whitlam was dismissed.
Following Whitlam's dismissal, [[Malcolm Fraser]] was appointed Prime Minister. He never had control of the House of Representatives, which immediately passed a motion of no confidence. However, the Governor-General had already accepted the advice of Fraser to dissolve parliament by the time of the motion of no confidence, and had already acted on it before he could receive the motion, so it was without effect.{{r|NAA}}
===[[Bulgaria]]=== *[[Philip Dimitrov]] (1992) - lost a vote of confidence
===[[Canada]]=== All no confidences are [[minority government]]s.
*[[Arthur Meighen]] (1926) - loss of confidence supply *[[John Diefenbaker]] (1963) - loss of confidence supply as a result of cabinet revolt *[[Pierre Trudeau]] (1974) - loss of confidence supply<ref>Trudeau lost a motion of confidence when he failed to pass the 1974 budget. However, it was later revealed that this was done purposely by Prime Minister Trudeau in a successful attempt to win a majority government. This is the only time the tactic has been used in federal Canadian politics, but it established a precedent. Such a tactic is now called "engineering the defeat of one's own government", and the practice is widely frowned upon.</ref> *[[Joe Clark]] (1979) - loss of confidence supply *[[Paul Martin]] (2005) - opposition triggered motion<ref name="Canada">While Meighen, Diefenbaker and Trudeau were toppled by [[loss of supply]], and Joe Clark was defeated by the passage of a subamendment to a budget bill that read "that this House has lost confidence in the government," Martin and Harper lost an actual motion of no confidence put forward by the opposition parties.</ref> *[[Stephen Harper]] (2011) - opposition triggered motion as a result of [[contempt of Parliament]] finding<ref name="Canada"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/story/2011/03/25/pol-defeat.html|title=Election looms as government falls|publisher=[[CBC News]]|date=25 March 2011|accessdate=25 March 2011}}</ref>
=== [[Cook Islands]] === * [[Terepai Maoate]] (2002)
===[[Croatia]]=== *[[Tihomir Orešković]] (2016) - lost a vote of no confidence triggered by ruling party after he called for his vice-PM (ruling party president)'s resignation due to [[conflict of interest]]

page.title: Man's Rights in the Family Party

revision.text:
{{infobox political party | leader = Yaakov Schlusser | founder = Yaakov Schlusser | founded = 1986 | ideology = [[Fathers' rights]]
[[men's rights]]
[[Masculism]]
[[Nationalism]]
[[Environmentalism]]
[[Human rights]] | country = Israel | native_name = {{Hebrew|מפלגת זכויות הגבר במשפחה - רע"ש}} }} The '''Man's Rights in the Family Party''' ({{lang-he|מפלגת זכויות הגבר במשפחה - רע"ש}}, ''Miflega Zkhuyot HaGever BeMishpaha - Ra'ash'') was a minor political party in [[Israel]] headed by [[Yaakov Schlusser]]. ==Background== In 1996, Schlusser published a book, ''Men's Rights in the Family?'',{{Cite book|title=זכויות הגבר במשפחה?|last=שלוסר|first=יעקב|publisher=שלוסר|year=1996|isbn=9657018056|location=תל אביב|pages=}} which argued that family law in the State of Israel is biased against men. Issues such as divorce, alimony, false accusations of abuse, and child support are addressed.{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120612043253/http://dhost.info/raash/book.html|title=Men's Rights in the Family? - book in PDF format|last=|first=|date=2012-06-12|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-05-27}} Schlusser subsequently contested the [[Israeli general election, 1996|1996 Knesset elections]] as the head of the Man's Rights in the Family Party. The platform of the party called for the abolition of the clause granting automatic custody to the mother in cases of divorce for small children. It also called for basing child support on other factors besides the cost-of-living index. Other issues the party dealt with was more housing for young couples, lowering taxes and a call for state pensions. It also called for the option of a secular civil marriage in addition to a religiously recognized marriage.{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120612043239/http://dhost.info/raash/layout.html|title=Archived website of Ra'ash party|last=|first=|date=2012-06-12|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-05-27}} It received 2,388 votes (0.1%), failing to win a seat. In the [[Israeli legislative election, 1999|1999 Knesset elections]] the party ran under the name "Justice for All" and received 1,257 votes (0.04%), the second lowest number of votes with a 1.5% [[Election threshold|electoral threshold]]. In 2003 the party was accused by the Israel Women’s Lobby of inciting violence against women and misrepresenting facts in their campaign broadcasts. However according to an article in ''Haaretz'', the chairman of the Central Elections Committee rejected the women's lobby petition to censor the campaign.{{cite web |url= http://www.haaretz.com/news/elections/cheshin-rejects-petition-to-censor-man-s-rights-in-the-family-ad-1.22163 |title= Cheshin rejects petition to censor Man's Rights in the Family ad |author= Alon, Gideon |date= January 15, 2003 |work= [[Haaretz]] |publisher= |accessdate=November 3, 2012}} In the subsequent [[Israeli legislative election, 2003|Knesset elections]], the party received 1,284 votes (0.04%). The [[Israeli legislative election, 2006|2006 elections]] saw the party run as "Justice for All" again, this time receiving 3,819 votes (0.12%). Prior to the [[Israeli legislative election, 2009|2009 Knesset elections]] Schlusser said in an interview with Yedioth Achronoth that one out of every two fathers loses the right to see their children as a result of messy divorces adding, "children have a right to see their fathers,"{{cite web |url= http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3637253,00.html |title= Men's Rights Party vies for votes |author= Edelson, Daniel |date= December 11, 2008 |work= [[Ynetnews]] |publisher= |accessdate= November 3, 2012}}{{cite web |url= http://www.jpost.com/LandedPages/PrintArticle.aspx?id=132546 |title= Smaller parties reckon with the political wilderness |author= Socol, Max |date= March 11, 2009 |work= [[The Jerusalem Post]] |publisher= |accessdate= November 3, 2012}} also claiming that "a child that sees a woman in control, in contradiction to nature, may turn homosexual". In the elections the party received only 921 votes (0.03%). In 2012 Schusser was profiled in ''Makor Rishon'' about his personal experiences which led him to run for public office.{{Cite web|url=https://www.makorrishon.co.il/nrg/online/54/ART2/414/823.html|title=יו''ר מפלגת זכויות הגבר: ''אני שווה לפחות 10 מנדטים''|website=NRG מעריב|access-date=2018-05-27}} In 2013 he advocated changing laws that stipulate stay-at-home men must pay National Insurance while housewives are exempt. In an interview with ''Haaretz'', he stated, "When it comes to the age of retirement, for example, women can retire at age 62, but I can't."{{Cite news|url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/business/mr-moms-suffer-from-insurance-law-1.5279298|title=Vive La Difference: Stay-at-home Men Liable for NII Payments|last=Weissberg|first=Hila|date=2013-10-25|work=Haaretz|access-date=2018-05-27|language=en}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110926210542/http://dhost.info/raash/main.html Official website] {{he icon}} {{Israeli political parties}} [[Category:Defunct political parties in Israel]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1996]] [[Category:Men's rights]] {{israel-party-stub}}

The [http://www.mpf.org.uk '''Methodist Peace Fellowship'''] is a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Methodist]] [[Christian pacifism|Christian pacifist]] organization.
The Methodist Peace Fellowship (MPF) was founded by Rev. Henry Carter in 1933 to inform and unite Methodists who covenanted together "to renounce war and all its works and ways."' It is part of the international [[Fellowship of Reconciliation]]. Members are expected to accept a fully pacifist position, but the MPF now encourages others to enrol as 'supporters'.
The MPF arranges a public meeting each year in connection with the British [[Methodist Conference]], and in other ways seeks to witness at national level through Methodist channels. The MPF has little local organisation with members usually working through the Fellowship of Reconicilation or local peace organisations.
At one time the Methodist Peace Fellowship claimed a quarter of all Methodist ministers among its members.
== External links == * [http://www.mpf.org.uk/ Methodist Peace Fellowship website]

==Key legislation== The Ministry of Primary Industries is responsible for administration of several key [[List of Acts of Parliament in Malaysia|Acts]]:
==Overview== The plantation and commodities sector, comprising oil palm, rubber, timber, cocoa, pepper and tobacco has contributed significantly to the country’s economic development for the past 50 years. Since then, the sector has become one of Malaysia’s major exports earnings. Exports values of these commodities and commodity based products in 2012 was RM 127.5 billion, constituted 18.2 per cent of total export earnings.
The remunerative price of commodities throughout 2012 has benefited the country, in particular the smallholders. The future of plantation industries and commodities sector remains bright and promises a lot of opportunities.
==Objectives== *To maximize the contribution of the commodity-based industries to national income including GDP and foreign exchange earnings. *To make Malaysia a centre of excellence in R&D, technology and services in commodity-based industries. *To increase the efficiency, productivity, quality and sustainability of primary industries based on K-economy. *To enhance marketing capabilities in order to increase market share particularly in niche markets.
==Functions== *To formulate policies and strategies for the overall development of the plantation and the commodity sectors. *To supervise departments and agencies under the Ministry on financial management and implementation of plantation and commodities development programs.

{{essay|date=May 2016}} {{Governance}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} '''Network governance''' is "interfirm coordination that is characterized by organic or informal [[social system]], in contrast to [[bureaucratic]] structures within firms and formal contractual relationships between them.<ref name="Jones et al 1997">{{Cite journal | last1 = Jones | first1 = Candace | last2 = Hesterly | first2 = William S. | last3 = Borgatti | first3 = Stephen P. | title = A general theory of network governance: exchange conditions and social mechanisms | journal = [[Academy of Management Review]] | volume = 22 | issue = 4 | pages = 911–945 | doi = 10.5465/AMR.1997.9711022109 | jstor = 259249 | date = October 1997 | ref = harv }}</ref> The concepts of [[privatization]], [[public private partnership]], and [[contracting]] are defined in this context." Network governance constitutes a "distinct form of coordinating economic activity" (Powell, 1990:301) which contrasts and competes with markets and hierarchies.<ref name="Dedeurwaerdere, 2007" />
== Definition ==
Network governance involves a select, persistent, and structured set of autonomous firms (as well as nonprofit agencies) engaged in creating products or services based on implicit and open-ended contracts adapt to environmental contingencies and to coordinate and safeguard ex-changes. These contracts are socially—not legally—binding. As such, governance networks distinguish themselves from the [[hierarchical control system|hierarchical control]] of the state and the competitive regulation of the market in at least three ways:<ref name="Sorensen and Torfing, 2005">{{Cite journal | last1 = Sørensen | first1 = Eva | last2 = Torfing | first2 = Jacob | title = The democratic anchorage of governance networks | journal = [[Scandinavian Political Studies]] | volume = 28 | issue = 3 | pages = 195–218 | doi = 10.1111/j.1467-9477.2005.00129.x | date = September 2005 | ref = harv }}</ref> #In terms of the relationship between the actors, governance networks can be described as a [[wikt:pluricentric|pluricentric]] system as opposed to the [[wikt:unicentric|unicentric]] system<ref name="Kersbergen & Waarden 2004">{{Cite journal | last1 = Van Kersbergen | first1 = Kees | last2 = Van Waarden | first2 = Frans | title = 'Governance' as a bridge between disciplines: cross-disciplinary inspiration regarding shifts in governance and problems of governability, accountability and legitimacy | journal = [[European Journal of Political Research]] | volume = 43 | issue = 2 | pages = 143–171 | doi = 10.1111/j.1475-6765.2004.00149.x | date = March 2004 | ref = harv | hdl = 1871/33908 }}</ref>(p. 151). Governance networks involve a large number of interdependent actors who interact with each other in order to produce an outcome.<ref name="Sorensen and Torfing, 2005" /> #In terms of decision making, governance networks are based on negotiation rationality as opposed to the substantial rationality that governs state rule and the procedural rationality that governs market competition<ref name="Scharpf, 1997">{{citation | last = Scharpf | first = Fritz | contribution = Actor-centered institutionalism | editor-last = Scharpf | editor-first = Fritz | title = Games real actors play actor-centered institutionalism in policy research | publisher = Westview Press | location = Boulder, Colorado | year = 1997 | isbn = 9780813399683 }}</ref> (p. 46) #Compliance is ensured through trust and political obligation which, over time, becomes sustained by self-constituted rules and norms.<ref name="Nielsen and Pedersen 1988">{{Cite journal | last1 = Nielsen | first1 = Klaus | last2 = Pedersen | first2 = Ove K. | title = The negotiated economy: ideal and history | journal = [[Scandinavian Political Studies]] | volume = 11 | issue = 2 | pages = 79–101 | doi = 10.1111/j.1467-9477.1988.tb00361.x | date = June 1998 | ref = harv }} [https://tidsskrift.dk/index.php/scandinavian_political_studies/article/view/12990/24777 Text.]</ref>
As a concept, Network Governance explains increased efficiency and reduced agency problems for organizations existing in highly turbulent environments. On the one hand, the efficiency is enhanced through distributed [[knowledge acquisition]] and decentralised problem solving; on the other, the effectiveness is improved through the emergence of collective solutions to global problems in different self-regulated sectors of activity.<ref name="Dedeurwaerdere, 2007"/> Due to the rapid pace of modern society and competitive pressures from [[globalization]], transnational network governance has gained prominence.<ref>Stone, Diane. Knowledge actors and transnational governance: The private-public policy nexus in the global agora. Palgrave Macmillan, 2013.</ref>
Network governance first depends on the comprehension of the short and long term global business risks. It’s based on the definition of the [[Information technology|IT]] key objectives and their influence on the network. It includes the negotiation of the satisfaction criteria for the business lines and integrates processes for the measurement and improvement of the global efficiency and end user satisfaction. Beyond that, it allows the constitution and piloting of internal teams and external partners as well as the setting up of a control system enabling to validate the performance of the whole. Finally, it ensures permanent communication at all the various management levels.
In the [[public sector]], network governance is not universally accepted as a positive development by all public administration scholars. Some doubt its ability to adequately perform as a [[democracy|democratic governance structure]] while others view it as phenomenon that promotes efficient and effective delivery of public goods and services. Examining managed networks in health care, Ferlie and colleagues<ref>{{cite book | last1 = Ferlie | first1 = Ewan | last2 = Fitzgerald | first2 = Louise | last3 = McGivern | first3 = Gerry | last4 = Dopson | first4 = Sue | last5 = Bennett | first5 = Chris | title = Making wicked problems governable? The case of managed networks in health care | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = Oxford | year = 2013 | isbn = 9781299441927 }}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal | last1 = Ferlie | first1 = Ewan | last2 = Fitzgerald | first2 = Louise | last3 = McGivern | first3 = Gerry | last4 = Dopson | first4 = Sue | last5 = Bennett | first5 = Chris | title = Public policy networks and 'wicked problems': a nascent solution? | journal = [[Public Administration (journal)|Public Administration]] | volume = 89 | issue = 2 | pages = 307–324 | doi = 10.1111/j.1467-9299.2010.01896.x | date = June 2011 | ref = harv }} [http://www.download.bham.ac.uk/hsmc/ewan-ferlie.pdf Pdf.]</ref> suggest that networks may be the 'least bad' form of governance addressing [[wicked problem]]s, such as providing health care for the increasing number of older people.
== Types == {{Expand section|date=July 2017}} Provan and Kenis categorize network governance forms along two different dimensions:<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Provan|first1=Keith G.|last2=Kenis|first2=Patrick|title=Modes of Network Governance: Structure, Management, and Effectiveness|journal=Journal of Public Administration Research and Theory|date=1 April 2008|volume=18|issue=2|pages=229–252|doi=10.1093/jopart/mum015|url=http://faculty.cbpp.uaa.alaska.edu/afgjp/PADM601%20Fall%202011/Modes%20of%20Network%20Governance.%202008.pdf|accessdate=17 July 2017|issn=1053-1858}}</ref> * Network governance may or may not be brokered. They refer to a network whose organizations interact with every other organization to decentralizedly govern the network "shared governance". At the other extreme a network may be highly brokered via centralized network brokers with only few and limited direct organization-to-organization interactions. * Network may be participant governed or externally governed.
===Participant-governed networks=== {{See also|Participation (decision making)|Self-governance|Group decision-making}} In participant governance a network is governed by its members themselves.
They call such networks that involve most or all network members interacting on a relatively equal basis in the process of governance "shared participant governance".
===Lead organization–governed networks=== More centralized networks may be governed by and through a lead organization that is a network member.
== Historical and modern examples of network governance == * In the 10th -13th Centuries, merchants in Cairo begin forming a network of merchants that report to each other the intents and information on agents working for them, and collectively inflict sanctions on agents that perform poorly. This leads to a hub of trading formed in Cairo and Aden – this makes the information on the market conditions, and the reputation of various agents easier to access for the good of the whole.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayBackIssues?jid=BHR|title=Business History Review|website=journals.cambridge.org|access-date=2016-04-13}}</ref> * By the 12th Century, Venice provides its merchants with an improved flow of information regarding the market conditions they face, as well as information on the practices of individual agents. This recording of information helps merchants make more informed business decisions.<ref name=":0" /> * The formation of the English and Dutch East India Companies forms a cooperation between merchants and companies to better regulate and inform others on the reputations of trading actors in London, Amsterdam and ports in East Africa and Arabia. This is a collective movement by governments and companies to raise capital for both the country and businesses.<ref name=":0" /> These examples show how Network Governance worked in the eras of increased trade and cooperation between merchants and nations ranging from the 10th Century to the 17th Century. Ron Harris, in his journal "Reputation at the Birth of [[Corporate governance|Corporate Governance]]. "The questions of who had a good reputation and who had a bad one, whom one could trust and entrust money to, were unaltered, but the relationships to which they applied changed, as did the institutions that provided answers to these questions."<ref name=":0" /> * [[AMBER Alert|Amber Alert]] - In 1996 the "Amber Alert" system was established after nine year old Amber Hagerman was kidnapped and murdered in Arlington, TX. Media networks, in collaboration with law enforcement, joined a grassroots movement to spread the cause in establishing a network to aide in broadcasting alerts in an effort to prevent future crimes. This movement has grown to include all fifty states, and spread alerts across state lines. The Amber Alert system has since been widely accepted as the first-response program for missing-persons nationwide.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Manna|first=Paul|date=June 2010|title=Network Governance in Three Policy Areas with Implications for the Common Core State Standards Initiative|url=|journal=Thomas B. Fordham Institute|doi=|pmid=}}</ref> * Homeland Security Fusion Centers – After the September 11th attacks, the United States endeavoured to improve the coordination between national and local organizations concerned with security. The [[United States Department of Homeland Security|Department of Homeland Security]] and a [[Director of National Intelligence]] were implemented at the federal level in response to this problem. Soon after, states began creating their own networks to share information pertinent to homeland security. As a result, fusion centers have popped up in almost every state, as well as many regions. These fusion centers provide a hub for law enforcement agencies to collaborate on national security measures in an effort to promote transparency across agencies, whether it be at the state, local or federal level.<ref name=":2" /> These are just two examples that help better explain network governance. A sharing of knowledge and information is at the center of the Amber Alert movement and the rise of Homeland Security Fusion Centers.
== Importance of governmental relations== Relationships among governing positions and governing institutions are absolutely vital for the success of the internal workings of the governments that aid the public. While federal, state, and local governments differ in their policies, they all work in coherence in order for the foundations to work efficiently.<ref>{{cite journal|jstor=259249}}</ref> "Checks and balances" is a prime synonym when referring to intergovernmental relations. All participating parties of the government must adhere to specific guidelines in order to cultivate a fair and even playing field that is both beneficial, and just to the population it affects.<ref name=":1" /> A primary principal in governmental relationships is the balance of power between the parties.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Forrer|title=Governing cross-sector collaboration|publisher=San Francisco, CA : Jossey-Bass, [2014]}}</ref> The Federal government has a large amount of control, in terms of national security, national finances and foreign affairs. However, in order to balance that control, state level governments have a significant voice in intrastate politics.<ref name="Newig et al, 2010" /> Specific examples of state level policies include topics such as state highways, borderlines, and state parks. This allows states to still have flexibility while bonding to national policy.
Unfortunately, creating relationships among different level governments and government agencies are a complicated, and often grueling process.<ref name="Haas 1992" /> However, many agencies make deals or come to terms or make a compromise within the party in order to further benefit both institutions. For example, a state may fund a county in order to better the county roads because it could be a direct reflection of the state. Intra-governmental relations between agencies, state level, local level, and federal level government must work together in order to prosper and create policies or laws that are beneficial to both the agencies and the public.<ref name="Warning,2006" />
== Role in environmental governance == <ref name="Newig et al, 2010" /> In the wake of apparent failures to govern complex environmental problems by the central [[Sovereign state|state]], "new" modes of [[governance]] have been proposed in recent years.<ref name="Newig et al, 2010">{{Cite journal | last1 = Newig | first1 = Jens | last2 = Günther | first2 = Dirk | last3 = Pahl-Wostl | first3 = Claudia | title = Synapses in the network: learning in governance networks in the context of environmental management | journal = [[Ecology and Society]] | volume = 15 | issue = 4 | id = article 24 | date = 2010 | url = http://www.ecologyandsociety.org/vol15/iss4/art24/ | ref = harv }}</ref> Network governance is the mode most commonly associated with the concept of governance, in which autonomous [[Stakeholder (corporate)|stakeholders]] work together to achieve common goals.
The emergence of network governance can be characterised by an attempt to take into account the increasing importance of [[NGOs]], the [[private sector]], scientific networks and [[international organisation|international institutions]] in the performance of various functions of governance.<ref name="Dedeurwaerdere, 2005">Dedeurwaerdere, T. 2005. [http://www.iddri.org/Activites/Seminaires-reguliers/s13_dedeurwaerdere.pdf The contribution of network governance to sustainable development].</ref> Embedding interventions to make society better and to transform conflicts within "relational webs"<ref>{{Cite book|title=The moral imagination : the art and soul of building peace|last=Paul.|first=Lederach, John|date=2010|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199747580|oclc=653082476}}</ref> can ensure better coordination with existing initiatives and institutions<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.fmreview.org/fragilestates/balyk-pugh.html|title=Networked governance in Ecuador's border regions {{!}} Forced Migration Review|website=www.fmreview.org|language=en|access-date=2017-06-15}}</ref>, and greater local acceptance and buy in, which makes the intervention more sustainable.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pugh|first=Jeffrey D.|date=2016-09-01|title=Peacebuilding Among Transnational Youth in Migrant-Receiving Border Regions of Ecuador|journal=Journal of Peacebuilding & Development|volume=11|issue=3|pages=83–97|doi=10.1080/15423166.2016.1222591|issn=1542-3166}}</ref> Prominent examples of such networks that have been instrumental in forming successful working arrangements are the [[World Commission on Dams]], the [[Global Environmental Facility]] and the [[flexible mechanisms|flexible mechanism]] of the [[Kyoto Protocol]].<ref name="Streck, 2002">{{citation | last = Streck | first = Charlotte | contribution = Global public policy networks as coalitions for change | editor-last1 = Esty | editor-first1 = Daniel C. | editor-last2 = Ivanova | editor-first2 = Maria H. | title = Global environmental governance: options & opportunities | pages = 121–140 | publisher = Yale School of Forestry & Environmental Studies | location = New Haven, Connecticut | year = 2002 | isbn = 9780970788221 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> Another ongoing effort is the [[United Nations Global Compact]] which combines multiple stakeholders in a trilateral construction including representatives from governments, private sector and the NGO community.<ref name="Haas, 2004">{{Cite journal | last = Haas | first = Peter M. | title = Addressing the global governance deficit | journal = [[Global Environmental Politics]] | volume = 4 | issue = 4 | pages = 1–15 | doi = 10.1162/glep.2004.4.4.1 | date = November 2004 | ref = harv | hdl = 1811/31977 }}</ref> (p. 6)
One main reason for the proliferation of network approaches in [[environmental governance]] is their potential to integrate and make available different sources of knowledge and competences and to encourage individual and collective learning.<ref name="Dedeurwaerdere, 2007">{{citation | last = Dedeurwaerdere | first = Tom | contribution = The contribution of network governance to sustainability impact assessment | editor-last1 = Thoyer | editor-first1 = Sophie | editor-last2 = Martimort-Asso | editor-first2 = Benoît | title = Participation for sustainability in trade | pages = 209–228 | publisher = Ashgate | location = Aldershot, England Burlington, Vermont | year = 2007 | isbn = 9780754683445 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref><ref name="Haas, 2004"/> Currently, environmental governance faces various challenges that are characterised by complexities and uncertainties inherent to environmental and sustainable problems.<ref name="Newig et al 2008">{{cite book | last1 = Newig | first1 = Jens | last2 = Voß | first2 = Jan-Peter | last3 = Monstadt | first3 = Jochen | title = Governance for sustainable development: coping with ambivalence, uncertainty and distributed power | publisher = Routledge | location = London | year = 2008 | isbn = 9780415451925 }}</ref> Network governance can provide a means to address these governance problems by institutionalising learning on facts and deliberation on value judgements.<ref name="Head, 2008">{{Cite journal | last = Palm | first = Brian W. | title = Assessing network-based collaborations: effectiveness for whom? | journal = Public Management Review, Special Issue: Collaborative Networks: New Performance Challenges | volume = 10 | issue = 6 | pages = 733–749 | doi = 10.1080/14719030802423087 | date = November 2008 | ref = harv }}</ref> For example, in the realm of global chemical safety, transnational networks have formed around initiatives by international organisations and successfully developed rules for addressing global chemical issues many of which have been implemented by national legislations. Most notably, these transnational networks made it possible to avoid the institutional apathy that is typically found in political settings with many actors of conflicting interests, especially on a global level.<ref name="Warning,2006">{{citation | last = Warning | first = Michael | contribution = Transnational bureaucracy networks: a resource of global environmental governance? | editor-last = Winter | editor-first = Gerd | title = Multilevel governance of global environmental change: perspectives from science, sociology and the law | pages = 305–329 | publisher = Cambridge University Press | location = Cambridge | year = 2006 | isbn = 9780521173438 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} [e-book] URL: [https://dx.doi.org/10.1017/CBO9780511720888.013 Details.]</ref>
Through integration of actors from different sectors, governance networks are able to provide an innovative environment of learning, laying the way for adaptive and effective governance.<ref name="Dedeurwaerdere, 2007"/> One particular form of networks important to governance problems is ‘[[epistemic community|epistemic communities]]’ in which actors share the same basic casual beliefs and normative values.<ref name="Haas 1992">{{citation | last = Haas | first = Peter M. | contribution = Introduction: epistemic communities and international policy coordination | editor-last = Haas | editor-first = Peter M. | title = Knowledge, power, and international policy coordination | pages = 1–35 | publisher = University of South Carolina Press | location = Columbia, South Carolina | year = 1997 | isbn = 9781570031755 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> (p. 3) Although participation in these epistemic communities requires an interest in the problem at stake, the actors involved do not necessarily share the same interest. In general, the interests are interdependent but can also be different or sometimes contesting, stressing the need for consensus building and the development of cognitive commodities.<ref name="Newig et al, 2010"/> (p. 26)
The main argument in the literature for the advantage of network governance over traditional [[command and control regulation]] or, alternatively, recourse to market regulation, is its capacity to deal with situations of intrinsic uncertainty and decision making under [[bounded rationality]].<ref name="Haas, 2004"/> This is typically the case in the field of global environmental governance where one has to deal with complex and interrelated problems. In these situations, network institutions can create a synergy between different competences and sources of knowledge allowing dealing with complex and interlined problems.<ref name="Dedeurwaerdere, 2007"/>
== Enhancement of Corporate Social Responsibility ==
As increasing amounts of scientific data validate concerns about the deterioration of our environment, the role of non-governmental organizations (NGOs) in network governance is being utilized in ever-increasing ways to halt or at least slow this deterioration. One of the ways they are accomplishing this is by directing their activities to focus on improving [[Corporate Social Responsibility]] (CSR). As a concept, CSR has existed since the first business was formed in civilization. The French philosopher Rousseau described it as the "social contract" between business and society.<ref>{{cite book | last = Rousseau | first = Jean-Jacques | title = The New Encyclopædia Britannica, Vol 26 | location = Chicago | pages = 938–942 | isbn = 9780852297872 }}</ref> As theories about CSR have evolved in keeping with their times, today it is increasingly associated with sustainable practices and development, meaning that businesses have a "moral responsibility" to conduct their operations in an ecologically sustainable manner.<ref name="Bichta, C. 2003">{{cite book | last = Bichta | first = Constantina | title = Corporate social responsibility: a role in government policy and regulation? | publisher = [[University of Bath]], School of Management | location = Bath | url = http://www.bath.ac.uk/management/cri/pubpdf/Research_Reports/16_Bichta.pdf | year = 2003 | oclc = 53860209 | access-date = 8 November 2011 }} Research report no. 16.</ref> It is no longer acceptable for corporations just to grow "the bottom line" and increase profits for their shareholders. Businesses remain free to pursue profits but are increasingly obligated to minimize their negative impact on the environment.<ref name="Bichta, C. 2003"/>
Network governance, in the form of NGOs, is effectively bringing to light "bad practices" by corporations, as well as highlighting those actively working to reduce their carbon footprints. Private governance networks such as CSRHUB and the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP) are entities that hold corporations accountable for their amount of corporate social responsibility. Founded to accelerate solutions to climate change and water management, the CDP discloses information and data on water management, greenhouse gas emissions, and climate change strategies on over 3,000 companies worldwide.<ref>{{cite web | title = Carbon Disclosure Project, CDP What We Do Online | url = https://www.cdproject.net/en-US/WhatWeDo/Pages/overview.aspx | access-date = 9 November 2011 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111103113627/https://www.cdproject.net/en-US/WhatWeDo/Pages/overview.aspx | archivedate = 3 November 2011 | df = dmy-all }} [Not dated.]</ref> It is the only global climate change reporting system and encourages corporations to engage in "best practices" regarding environmental impact by making their formerly private or unknown environmental impact information available to anyone, including the general public. This information can be used (by a variety of entities) to make consumer purchase and investment decisions, formulate governmental as well as corporate policy, educate people, develop less harmful business methods for corporations and formulate action plans by environmental advocacy groups, to name a few. "The first step towards managing carbon emissions is to measure them because in business what gets measured gets managed. The Carbon Disclosure Project has played a crucial role in encouraging companies to take the first steps in that measurement and management path".<ref>{{cite web | title = Synergy Carbon, Carbon Strategy Services Online |url = http://www.synergycarbon.com/carbon-strategy-services | date = 2006 | access-date = 10 November 2011 }}</ref> This quote by Lord Adair Turner, Chairman of the UK Financial Services Authority, illustrates how network governance is enhancing CSR.
Leading European business schools joined with more than sixty multinationals to launch the [[Academy of Business in Society]], the mission of which is to push CSR to the forefront of business practice. Their main activities in pursuing this goal are: 1 )developing ‘best-in-class’ training practices and learning resources for businesses and corporate academies, 2) including the changing role of business in society in business education and 3) creating a global research bank on the role of business in society and delivering interdisciplinary research on CSR.<ref name="Bichta, C. 2003"/> This is an example of network governance using education to improve Corporate Social Responsibility. Use of organization of networks in today’s society is a valid means of moving forward in preserving our environment.
